sp.p: We by faith understand that we are justified by Christ, and when ever Scripture saith, We are justified by faith, by the word Faith is meant Christ, if properly spoken, because faith cannot justifie us.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: First, We say with Scripture, We are justified by faith: but we do not say, Faith justifieth us. Herein you wrong us.

Secondly, when Scripture saith, We are justified by Faith, it doth not by the word Faith mean Christ; for, the Faith by which we are justified, is the Faith of Iesus, and Faith in Iesus Christ, rom. 3.22, 26. Gal. 2.16. Phil. 3.9. It is a believing in him, Gal. 2.16. Yea, it is a Faith perfected by Workes, and declared to be lively by Workes, Iam. 2

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: First, Scripture gives the name of things to the likenesse of them, as the likenesse of Samuel called Samuel, 1.28. An image called God, and the Priests offerings said to cleanse, Lev. 30.20.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p:
Is Christ but the likenesse of Faith? or, Is Faith a god? and Christ the image of this god? For, say you,
Christ is called Faith, as the likenesse of a thing hath the name of the thing: this particular might have been weighed first, and then penned.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Secondly, We are justified by faith as well as by Workes before men, Iames 2.24.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: By Workes before men, but by faith before God, rom. 4.2, 3, 4. Also that Faith by which we are are justified appeares lively by Workes, Iames 2.14. to the end.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Thirdly, because Faith as a relative depends on Christ, where one is, the other is also.
Fourthly, Faith is most for God, and is not the cause but the effect of Iustification.

sp.speaker: Kilc
sp.p: These are Truths, if we call belief faith, but falsehood, if we call Christ Faith; for Christ depends not on Christ as a relative: also, Christ is not the effect, but the cause of Iustification, Isay 53.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Secondly, Faith cannot justifie; for it is not our righteousnesse nor Iustification, neither doth it free us from bondage, nor present us holy, &c. But Scripture attributes each of these to Christ, and we may as well attribute Iustification to prayer as to faith.
Thirdly, Faith cannot justifie us, because it is imperfect, that as well as other things in us is as filthy ragges.

Fourthly, Believing justifies not because it is a worke, and a worke it is, for the littlenesse of it is reprovable, and we are exhorted to abound therein. It is obedience to a command; yea, every soul-faculty is therein imployed. Yea, Faith is a receiving, and receiving is a worke; yea, It is necessary in every good worke; yea, Believers do believe; If objected, that Faith is put in opposition to Workes. I answer, that by Faith then is alwayes meant Christ; and when ever Workes are about Iustification excluded, Faith is one.

Fifthly, Faith in a strict sense justifieth not the conscience;
science; but the Spirit witnesseth, rom. 8.16. Faith is not one of the three Witnesses, recorded 1 John 5. And if Faith could justifie, it would be greater than love, but love is greater, 1 cor. 13. And we might better say, we are justified by Scripture, for thereby we know it.

Sixthly, Believing justifies not, for all justified ones are justified before they believe; for God justifieth sinners, enemies, ungodly: and Believers are to believe that they are justified, and that their finnes are pardoned already, Isay 40.1, 2. Therefore we are so before we believe; and this the Spirit of Truth witnesseth, 1 Iohn 5.6.

Seventhly, because such as say they are justified by believing, know not what to stand to, whither the act, or Nature unacted; if the Nature unacted, then I demand, how the Nature without acting can be known.
Secondly, how the Nature without acting can be called Faith.

Thirdly, how then we can tell how, or when we are justified: and if saith can be one houre in the soul without acting; Why not houres, yea, yeares? And if the act be not righteousnesse, but accounted so; whither then, God accounts not that righteousnesse which is not; and whither this dishonours not God and Christ, as if his Bloud were not sufficient.

And if the act justifie, I demand, whither one or many? If one, Which? If many, How many? And if we must continually act, as we continually sin, then we are not compleatly justified yet; neither can we say three minutes together that we are so.

Eighthly, the holding that believing justifieth, brings in many Errours with it; as, that God accepts for Faith, and respects Faith more than Christ, that Christs Death is without effect, that Faith is the cause of Iustification, that righteousnesse is in part of our selves, that Instification
consisteth in acts of obedience: and so Faith is set on Christs Throne.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: These eight Reasons you bring to prove that Faith doth not, and cannot justifie: but you might well have spared this labour: because the Objection which you here Answer, doth not say, Faith doth or can justifie: and so you in these eight Reasons do but beat the ayre. First, uttering an expression which the Objectour dares not utter, and then with might and main you confute your own Expression. If it be a Truth, Why do you confute it? And if it be a Errour, (as indeed it is) Why did you first frame it? And this might suffice for a Reply to this answering the Objection: for you speak not to the thing in hand, but quite beside it, the Obiection remaines still unanswered; and these eight Reasons are quite beside it, for the Objection doth say, we are justified by Faith, and so saith abundance of Scriptures; but it doth not say, Faith justifieth.
Yet the better to clear the Truth to the doubtfull, I shall speak a little to them orderly.

And the first being spoke to, to the second I reply, that (as you say) Christ is our righteousnesse, reconciliation, freer from bondage, presenter of us holy, &c. and Faith is not. But Brother, Who attributes these things to Faith? This Objection doth not.
To the third I reply, I grant Faith is in us, in respect of measure imperfect, but not in respect of nature, but is pretious, yea most holy, 2 peter 1.1, 2. Jude 20.

To the fourth, 'Tis true, Faith is a worke, yea, not onely a worke, but The worke, John 6.29. Yet it is not one of those workes which is excluded about Iustification; for, A man is justified by saith, without the Workes of the Law, rom. 7 27, 28. He that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, his Faith is counted for righteousnesse, rom. 4.5. & 9.32.

Also, that Faith which about Iustification is put in opposition to Workes is not Christ, for that Faith opposed to Workes, and by which we are justified, is The Faith of Iesus Christ, Faith in Jesus Christ, Gal. 2.16. rom. 3.22, 26. Yea, that Faith that is perfected by Workes. Seest thou not how his Faith wrought by Workes, and by Workes was his Faith perfected; and the Scripture fulfilled, which saith, Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him for righteousnesse, Jam. 2.22, 23.

To the fifth I reply, that what the Spirit witnesseth, and the Word reveales, Faith receiveth, 1 John 5.8, 9, 10. And 'tis safest to say, We are justified by that that the Word saith we are justified by: and though it be not material whither Faith or Love is greatest; yet the Faith minded to be lesse than Love, 1 cor. 13. is such a Faith as may be where Love is not, and not that Faith that workes by Love.

To the sixth I reply, that People before God justifieth them are ungodly, but not afterward, whom he justifieth, he findeth ungodly, but leaves them not so, but justifieth them, that is, makes them righteous which were unrighteous. Secondly, though he justifieth the ungodly, he doth not iustifie the unbeliever, but gives them Faith, Ephes. 2.8. And so his iustification is unto and upon all that believe. None else, God is iust and a Justifier of him that believes on Jesus, from all things from which he could not be iustified by the Law of Moses, rom. 3.22, 26. Acts 10.39. And your saying that Isay 40.1, 2. bids me believe that our Iustification is past, or that 1 Iohn 5.6. saith, The Spirit witnesseth so, is false.

Your likeliest place, to wit, Isay 40. is a Prophesie, and not a History; as appeares. First, by your own ground: for Christ had not in Isays time suffered. 2ly, Jerusalems warfare was then in being. Thirdly, the
place plainly declares the time yet to come in which these tidings shall be. Marke it well, God will say (to his Messengers) comfort ye, comfort ye my people. Tell Jerusalem, Her warfare is accomplisht, her sin is pardoned.

To the seventh I say, If we do not know what to stand to, you might in love teach us, but this we do stand to, that We are iustified by faith; and sith, (as you grant) the nature of Faith cannot be without acting, your distinguishing the one from the other is vain: and sith we stand to what Scripture speakes, namely, that We are iustified by faith: though some are not Logicians to tell you, whither it be by nature without act, or act without nature, or both together, it matters not, your distinction being froathy.

To the eighth I reply, that these are Errours indeed; but we do not say, Faith iustifieth, this expression is not ours but yours; and so these Errours fall on your head, not on ours; we say, We are iustified by Faith: we do not say, Faith iustifieth.

div.p: Object. 19. We are not iustified by Faith alone, but by Christ and Faith together.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: This is as bad, in making Christ but halfe a Saviour. 2. Why do you not to Christ and faith, adde prayer and good Workes, phil. 1.19. Iames 2.24. Thirdly, If Faith be Christs partner in accomplishing the worke, it must have part of the glory also.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: That these things follow the ioyning Christ and Faith as partners together, I grant; but I suppose that you framed not onely this Answer, but this Obiection also: for you are the first that ever I heard utter such a speech, though it is true, that Iustification is by Christ, for he hath purchased it, and true also that we are iustified by Faith, for Faith applyeth it: yet Faith is not Christs partner therein; for it is by Christ in one respect, and by Christ in another, and not by both in one and same respect.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You deny we are iustified by Christ, in saying, We were not presented holy before we believe, you contradict Christ himselfe, Ephes. 5.27. Iohn 19.28-30. O treason, treason, against Christ! Note this.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Christ doth not in Iohn 19. nor in Ephes. 5. or any where else say, that he presented us holy before we believe, and therefore our saying, we were not, doth not contradict Christ; and your saying It doth, is untruth. Secondly, Ephes. 5.17. saith otherwise as hath been minded, chap. 2. And so if gain-saying or perverting Scripture be Treason, you are guilty, and not we in this thing; and your crying Treason, treason, is but a Scare-crow to frighten People from embracing the truth.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Obj. 20. It is God, and not Faith that justifieth, but he justifieth by Faith, not without it.

sp.speaker: Samuel Richardson.
sp.p: THrough Faith, that is, through Christ, as through his Bloud, Ephes. 1.7. Through redemption in him, rom. 3.24. Through him and by him are all one, Ephes. 1.5, 6. Gal. 3.14. But if you will have it through Faith, it must be so through it as through a pipe; for we do through Faith as through a prospect-glasse see and receive our righteousnesse by Christ, we receive the promise through Faith, Gal. 3.14.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p:
Yea Brother, we must have it through faith, because Scripture saith, It is through faith. Secondly, the sense you now minde is the very sense that holds. Thirdly,
'Tis well you yield to Truth at last; had you done so all this while we should at the farthest distance but have tryed out in what sense we are iustified by Christ, and in what sense by faith: but you have till now most stoutly affirmed, that we are not iustified by faith, though many Scriptures saith we are; and to make your word good against such Scriptures, you have with all your might laboured to maintain, that by the word Faith is meant Christ: one Errour it seemes will call in another for assistance.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: And this we grant, for we can distinguish betwixt our fight, Ezek. 20.43. and Gods sight, Job 9.20. Our sustification in Gods sight was before all time: for, People without sin, without sault before his Throne, revel. 15.5. cant. 4.7. Whose finnes are laid on Christ, Isay 53.11. Against whom is no charge, rom. 8.33. Those which are in Christ, and reconciled, 2 cor. 5. Iustified and redeemed, Ephes. 1.7. Whose sinnes are remitted and not imputed to them, must needs be righteous in Gods sight: but the Elect were so when Christ dyed; yea, before the World was, but manifest when he appeared, 1 Tim. 1.9, 10.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p:
'Tis good to distinguish betwixt our sight and Gods; we being dim, and he quick-fighted. All things are naked before him, Hebr. 4.13. While we are finners, unbelievers, and uniustified, he seeth us so, and he will see us to be iustified and cleansed when we are so, he seeth us spotty while we are spotty, he doth not see us to be spotlesse till we are spotlesse, he doth not see us through a glasse darkly, much lesse through a false glasse, he seeth us iust as we be; if we see our selves silthy, he seeth it more clearly; if our hearts condemne us, he much more, 1 Iohn 3. And so to your Reason I reply, that when we are without sin or fault, when God cannot lay ought to our charge, when we are redeemed, our
sinnes remitted, not imputed to us, &c. then we shall be righteous in Gods fight, but not before, and this is at Christs next appearing, as before proved.

If you say, God saw us righteous before the world was; then I say, God also before the world was saw Christ appearing. If you say God saw us iustified from eternity; I say, God also from eternity saw us Believers: so that we are not iustified in Gods sight, till we are Believers in Gods sight; God doth not see us compleat before God seeth Christs second comming.
Object. 21. By Faith, rom. 4.13. is not meant Christ, for Scripture never calleth Christ Faith.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: By the word Faith there is meant Christ, because he is our righteousnesse. For,

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Though Christ be our righteousnesse, yet the word Faith is not Christ, for Christ is our righteousnesse through saith: Him we have won, and in him we are found: when we have that righteousnesse, which is through the faith of Christ, phil. 3.9.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: 1. Faith and Christs righteousnesse are severall things, 2 peter 1.1.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Also Christ and the Faith of Christ by which we are iustified are severall things, Gal. 2.16.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: 2. God hath made Christ our righteousnesse, 1 cor. 1.30. 3. The Title, The Lord our righteousnesse, belongs onely to him, Ier. 23.6.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: This is true, and as true that He is our righteousnesse, or The Lord our righteousnesse, through faith he is not our propitiation, much lesse Iustification, otherwise than Through Faith in his Bloud; thus God sets him forth, rom. 3.25.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Fourthly, Faith is not our righteousnesse, for Faith shall cease, but our righteousnesse shall be for ever, Isay 51.8.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p:
You again wrest the Obiection, which doth not
say, Faith is our righteousnesse, but it saith, The Faith specified rom. 4.13. is not Christ.
Secondly, the everlasting righteousnesse which Christ purchased is ours by Faith, as before proved.
Thirdly, you did say, It was conveighed through Faith as through a pipe, or seen through Faith as through a prospect-glasse, and have you already forgot it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Fifthly, Christs righteousnesse is as a garment without us, not within us, but Faith is within us, revel. 19.8. & 7.9-13. Isay 61.10.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Christ (which as you say) is made unto us righteousnesse is not only without and about us, but within us also: He dwels in our hearts by Faith, Ephes. 3.17. Also I could tell you that these Scriptures are not yet accomplisht. But of this before.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sixthly, our righteousnesse is in Christ, not in us, 2 cor. 5.21. Isay 45.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: That righteousnesse should be in Christ, and Christ by faith in us, and yet the said righteousnesse not in us, is more strange than true.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Our righteousnesse was not brought in in Daniels time, but at seventy VVeekes end, Dan. 9.24. But Faith was brought in before, even in Abrahams time.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: That righteousnesse which is through faith must needs be as soon as faith through which it is. I thinke.

Secondly, righteousnesse through faith was brought in in Abrahams time, as it is brought in now; for he is as a paterne held forth to us; that iust as it was with him it shall be with all that become righteous. He believed, and it was counted to him for righteousnesse, rom. 4.
Thirdly, It was then brought in, in respect of promise; and it is not yet brought in, in full accomplishment, we are not crowned with righteousnesse yet, 1 Tim. 4.8.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Eighthly, the Saints counted Christ, and not faith their righteousnesse, psal. 71.16-24. Ier. 13.29.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: The Obiection which you now answer, doth not say, that the Saints account Faith, or account not Christ their righteousnesse: also the Saints did by faith receive Christ their righteousnesse; as before proved.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Ninthly, Christ is all in all, and in all things to have the preheminence, col. 1.18. 3.11. Ephes. 1.23.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Paul who reckoned Christ all in all, and yielded him the preheminence sought that righteousnesse which is through the Faith of Christ, phil. 3.8, 9.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: If faith could have been righteousnesse to us, Christ might have been spared.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Also, Were Christ our righteousnesse without or before believing, faith might be spared: then also unbelievers would share as deep in Christ as believers: but they do not, phil. 3.8, 9.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Eleventhly, Faith is not this righteousnesse, for this righteousnesse is through faith, phil. 3.9. rom. 3.15.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: Your whole drift in your large Answers to the 18, 20. and this 21. Obiection hath been to maintein, that when ever Scripture saith, We are justified through faith: by the word Faith is meant Christ: for, 'Tis through him: and now you say, Faith cannot be our righteousnesse, for it is through Faith.
If by the word faith here, (as you by your rule teach) is meant Christ, then in proper speech it is, that Christ cannot be our righteousnesse, because our righteousnesse is through Christ.

You oft times say, Christ is righteousnesse: and oft you say, that Our righteousnesse is through Christ: and here you say, that cannot be our righteousnesse through which it is: and how these things will hold together, Iudge Reader. But the Truth is, you would now have the word Faith to be meant Faith and not Christ, as indeed it is, yet this reason with the ten reasons before
it, is brought to prove that by the word Faith, rom. 4.13. is meant Christ; and to answer that Obiection that saith, It is not.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Twelftly, the Saints expect not acceptation, for ought in them, or acted by them, but mention Christs righteousnesse only, psal. 71.10-16.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: And Paul was in this Saint-like temper, in seeking to be found in Christ, that is, not having his own, but that righteousnesse which is through the faith of Christ, phil. 3.8, 9. So that we may say, (as Scripture doth) that Righteousnesse is through Faith in Christ Iesus, and yet not expect acceptation for ought acted by us, but onely make mention of his righteousnesse.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Thirteenthly, Faith apart from Christ is no righteousnesse at all, 1 cor. 15.17. Though filled with Christ the powerfullest thing that is, Ephes. 3.16. He is our Bread, Iohn 6. Our Life, Gal. 2.20. Which Life we now enioy by faith, which Faith evidenceth things not seen, but some make a god of believing, fetch their comfort from it, and venter their salvation on it, had they lived on, and prised Christ as their believing, I had spared my labour.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: But Faith cannot be apart from Christ, Hebr. 6.19, 20. yea, you affirme p. 28. that Faith as a relative depends on Christ; so that where one is the other is also: and that you should see these inseparable, and yet when you please, separate them, is to me strange. Secondly, 'Tis true that Christ is our Bread, and Life, &c. But he is thus by Faith; he by believing is received and become ours, Iohn 1.12. He that believeth on him, hath him; and he that hath him hath life; he that hath not him hath not life, 1 Iohn 5.10, 11, 12.

Thirdly, that our present enjoyments are by faith; and that faith is an evidence of things unseen is the thing I maintain. And had you thus wrote alwayes, I had spared
my labour in opposing you: this being that that I stand for.
Fourthly, those that make a god of their believing have not (I thinke) the faith of Gods Elect: but we do not in saying (as Scripture saith) that We are iustified by faith, make a god of believing.
Fifthly, your labour herein hath not been to confute such as make a god of believing, or that extoll that above Christ; but to confute such as do say, We are iustified by faith in Iesus Christ.
Object. 22. Abraham believed God, and it was imputed to him for righteousnesse.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: So Phinehas executed Iudgement which was imputed to him for righteousnesse, Psal. 106.30. that is, a righteous action.

Secondly, If Abrahams believing were counted for righteousnesse, then it was his righteousnesse, but Christ onely is so; for nothing makes us righteous but he, rom. 5.19. And believing implies righteousnesse in another, rom. 4.7. He is our righteousnesse, Jer. 23.6. Peace, Eph. 2.14. Propitiation, rom. 3.25. Redeemer, Saviour, eternal Life; who hath him, hath all; who hath not him, hath nothing.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: That faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousnesse is Scripture, romans 4.9. That then it was his righteousnesse is your consequence.

Secondly, that faith, and also executing Iudgement are both righteous actions, I grant, and adde another expression of yours, that Faith is a requisite in every good worke, without which it is not well done, nor pleasing to God. And this also is a Truth, Hebr. 11.6. Abel offering in faith was accepted, And he had the witnesse that he was righteous, verse 4. Noah by faith did what he did, And became heir of the righteous, which is by faith, verse 5. Thus with Enoch, Abraham, Jacob, Moses, Barak,
Gidion, Sampson; yea all, Hebr. 11. their Actions being not onely things commanded, but also done in faith were righteous Actions, not else; and so Phinehas his Action had not been imputed for righteousnesse, had it not been done in faith, and Christ is our Propitiation, no otherwise than through faith, rom. 3.25. He that believes hath Christ, and with him all things; he that believes not hath nothing, as in your quotation, 1 John 5.10, 11, 12. Christ is indeed our meritorious righteousnesse, and peace, &c. But, Is ours by faith? Also, we do not say, Faith, or any thing beside Christ (as God) can make us righteous. But you wrest our words as you do Scripture.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Object. Justification is after calling, Rom. 8.30.

sp.speaker: Samuel Richardson.
sp.p: THen not by faith, for we believe when we are called; and if we are Believers, and yet not justified; it is because it could not iustifie.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p: We may be justified by faith, and yet not till after we believe: for faith applyeth things to come, Hebr. 11.1, 2.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Secondly, though the Elect are justified before they believe, yet they receive it not till then; they receive it by faith, Acts 10.43. We receive our priviledges in this order; first calling, then Iustification, and then glorification.

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p:
That God should worke after one order, and faith receive after another; that God should iustifie first,
and call afterward; and a grounded faith apply, calling first, and Iustification afterward, is more strange than true.

Secondly, rom. 8.30. speakes of Gods orderly working, and not of our receiving; the words are, Moreover whom he predestinated, them he also called, and whom he called, them he also iustified, and whom he iustified, them he (to wit, God) also glorified.

Thirdly, Acts 10.43. speakes not of that receiving, remission of sinnes that is by faith, but of another receiving, which followeth believing; To him give all the Prophets witnesse that through his Name whoever believeth on him shall receive remission of sinnes. Whosoever for the present believeth shall receive, &c. to wit, afterward.
Obiect. 24. Faith is a condition required to salvation; for, He that believeth and is baptized shall be saved, he that believes not shall be damned, Marke 16.16.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: 1. Faith is no cause or condition of salvation, but this is a rule for Gospel preaching. 2. If faith be a requisite without which we cannot be saved, then is salvation by Works. 3. Then is the covenant of grace, neither free or absolute; if obiected, God gives what he requires. I answer, Then is the condition easie to be performed, but a condition it is still; but it is free without condition on our part. For,

sp.speaker: Kilc.
sp.p:
1. I will not uphold this Obiection. 2. You do wrest the Obiection, in adding the word cause; for a condition required thereto is one thing, and and a cause thereof is another, this being (as you grant a rule for Gospel preaching, Gospel preachers should observe it: but you in saying We may be saved without believing, go against this rule. 4. Though faith be not a conditional cause of, yet it is so requisite to salvation, that whoso believes not (to wit, at all) shall be damned, Marke 16. and never see life, but abide under wrath, and die in his
sins, Joh. 3.36. & 8.21-24. 5ly, Gods working in us, what he requireth of us, doth not disanul, but extol his freenes, and tendeth to the comfort & not the discomfort of the Saints, so that they can bodly say, To us Lord thou wilt ordain peace: for thou hast wrought al our works for us, Isa. 26.12.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: First, The Covenant of grace was never made with man, but with Christ onely, Ps. 89.19-24-27. Secondly, therefore nothing as a condition, without which they cannot be sav'd, is of the elect required, Heb. 8.10. Salvation dependeth not on believing, but on Christ, John 14.19. Because I live, ye shall live.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: 1. Without arguments, Scripture may prove the Covenant of grace to be free; But that would be needlesse, being not herein opposed. But your saying, God never made it with man, but only with Christ, is comfortlesse and false; comfortles: for if made only with Christ; it must be performed onely with Christ. False, for first, Ps. 89. doth not say, it was not made with man. 2. It was made with Abraham, Gen. 17.1. and with his seed, vers. 7. with the whole house of Israel and house of Iudah, Jer. 31.32, 33, 34. Heb. 8.8. Eze. 34.25. but these are men Eze. 34.30, 31. and I by faith, depend on Christ for salvation: also these words, because I live, ye shall also. Christ spake to believers.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Thirdly, Faith is a fruit of this Covenant. 4. The Elect were ever in this Covenant, being ever in Christ, which is this Covenant. Eph. 1.3, 4. Esay. 42.6. & 49.9.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p:
Faith is no fruit of this Covenant, for it was not made with any till they did believe: when it was made with Abraham, he was a believer, and his feed with whom it is made, and shall be establisht, are onely the believing feed, In Isaac this seed is called, Gen. 17.19.21.12. that is, The children of the promise, and not the children after the flesh, are counted for the seed. Ro. 9.7.8. such as are Christs are Abrahams seed, and heirs according to promise, Gal. 3.29. & 4.28, 31. And they that are Christs have crucified the flesh with the affections and lusts, Gal. 5.24. mark it
well. Such as have not (in some measure) crucified the flesh, &c. are not Christs, Gal. 4.24. and they that are not Christs, are not Abrahams seed according to promise, Gal. 3.29. but God doth make, and will establish his Covenant with that seed only, which is according to promise, Gen. 17.19.21.12. 25th Object. To be justified, is to be pronounced just.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: To be justified, is to be made just.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: To be justified, is to be made just: it hath more in it then a bare pronuntiation.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Men are made just, when the habit of justice is put into them: so God made man. Eccl. 7.29.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: And when this habit of justice (being now lost) is by Christ to us restored, we shall be justified or made just.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 2. Men are made just, by the justice of another. Christs satisfaction, is our justification. As by one mans disobedience many were made sinners: so by the obedience of one, many are made righteous, Rom. 5.19. 2 Cor. 5.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: First, Rom. 5.19. is by you abused, which saith, So by the obedience of one, many shall be made righteous. But you write many are. Secondly, you also confound your selfe, in saying, His satisfaction is our juctification, and also saying, We are justified by his justice, as if not only his obedient suffering, but also his holy walking, were imputed to us, which cannot stand with Gods justice, as before declared. Thirdly, His satisfaction procureth, but is not our justification: his bearing iniquity is the cause, justification the effect. Esay. 53.11.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: We are made just by sentence: so men justify themselves, Job 9.20. or the wicked, Prov. 17.15. This is oft times worth nothing, being but a shadow.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Therefore, though you and a thousand more tell me, that your justification is already effected, I seeing remnants of injustice in you, believe you not; knowing such words to be but winde: God will not say it, till it be so: He will nor clear the guilty, Ex. 34.7.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
But declaring one just, maketh him not so: for first,
then he was not so before. 2. Then we make God so (which is blasphemy) 3. Then tis good to justify the wicked.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: These ill consequences fall on their heads that doe say, Declaring a man iust doth make him so, not on others.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 4. God by his Spirit, declares to our souls, that we are iust, which if we were not when he was on the crosse, then he iustifieth the wicked: they being iust or wicked; if iust, then, his declaring them to be so, makes them not so: if not iust, then wicked; and he will not clear the guilty. Ex. 34.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: That God clears not the guilty is true, and as true, that you and I are as yet in some things guilty, and therefore though I dare not think you destitute of Gods Spirit, yet sure I am, that Gods Spirit doth not declare unto your soul, that you are in accompishment instified already, but are in respect of purpose, prophesie, promise, purchase, and faith (that is) God hath purposed, and promised it, Christ hath purchased it, and Faith applieth it. Believers were iustified in respect of purpose, before the world was, in respect of prophesie and promise before Christ dyed: In respect of purchase when he dyed; and by faiths application, when they believe, and shall be iustified effectually in accomplishment, in performance, and in respect of actuall enioyment, when Christ again appeareth, but not before, as hath been proved: he came to purchase, and will come to effect.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 5. Men are not iustified, because declared so to be, but declared to be so, because they are so.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Therefore, God will not declare us iust till we are: and your saying you are iust, before you are, is untrue.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
In iustification are three essentials: sinners to be made iust, God to make iust, and the means by which, is Christs blood, Rom. 5.10. Isaiah said, He should iustifie many, 45.25. which he fulfilled, when he was made sinne, Is. 53.11. 2 Cor. 5.21. iustification is where satisfaction is, as all in Adam by his disobedience were made sinners: so
all in Christ by his obedience were made righteous Rom. 5.14. &c.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: These requisites in iustification, to wit, sinners to be made, God to make iust, and Christs bloud as a means to procure it, I own: but that he when he dyed, effected what he dyed for, I deny: but the effect followeth the cause. He hath been, that we might be, 2 Cor. 5.21.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Iustification, is first to be considered in purpose: Thus the Elect were saved ere the world was, 2 Tim. 1.9, 10. which is called Iustification, Tit. 3.7. to wit, in respect of purpose.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: That it is already in purpose and purchase to, I maintain: and that it is effected or accomplisht, is that which I deny.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 2. It is to be considered in the effecting and executing of it, by the means Iesus Christ, who did justifie many, Is. 53. Rom. 5.19. it is actually done, as the Priests bore Israelites names, Ex. 28.21. So Christ bore their names and persons, who should be iustified and saved, Hebr. 2.11.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: I have declared that Christ hath but purchased, and not effected iustification, as yet, though he shall. And your quotations, Is. 53. Rom. 5.19. say, he shall, and doe not say (as you doe) that he did justifie, and as Aaron the Type, so Christ the antitype, doth by interceding bear the names of such as shall be iustified and saved: Ergo. They are not iustified and saved as yet.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Christ tooke not onely the nature, but also the persous of the elect: else he answereth not the types, else he did as much for all, as any; yea, else he bore not the sins of any.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Your disjoyning a mans nature from his person, is as frivolous as your former setting faith a part from Christ, and the act of faith from the nature of it, and therefore not worth the answering.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
Iustification being accomplisht, it is Christs pleasure
to reveale it, to those to whom it belongeth, by his Spirit, Word and Ordinances, that they might enjoy the comfort of it: the effect of which declaration, begetteth in them love to God, and carrieth the soul out of it self to Christ, &c.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: The discoveries of love, doth indeed produce such effects; but to say the effect of such declarations, begets love, &c. is non-sense: for our love to God, is the effect of his declarration of love to us, 1 John 4.17. Secondly, God discovers Iustification to those to whom it belongeth before it be accomplisht: therefore its so often said, We are instified by faith. Yea, your point proves this, for the accomplishment heerof was, say you, when Christ dyed: but it was discovered, to Abraham and other believers before Christ dyed.

Thirdly, When iustification is accomplisht, we shall have such union with God, and knowledge of God, that we shall not need word or ordinances to discover it to us; neither want the comfort of it, when (in accomplishment) all the seed of Israel shall be iustified, they shall glory, Is. 45.25.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: The efficient cause of iustification, or salvation, is Gods love: the materiall cause, Christs death: the end or finall cause, Gods glory.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: These causes I deny not: but adde this, That the meritorious cause goes before the effect: but of this before.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: The work being done, the Spirit reveals, faith believeth, and good workes declare that it is done for us.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p:
The Spirit reveals, and faith receives things as they be, or as the word holdeth them forth: Namely, first, in promise, afterwardin performance: first, purchased, afterward effected; the spirit revealeth, and faith receiveth Christ come, a high Priest of good things to come, Hebr. 9.11. Now to your quotations. The Spirit revealing, Rom. 8.16. hath
not reference to the time past nor present, but to the glory that shall be shewed to us, as verse 17, 18. and Acts 26.18. speaks of that receiving remission of sins, &c. that is after sanctification, by faith in Christ.
26. Object. Iustification is onely in the conscience, and men are not iustified till sin be taken out of their conscience.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Iustification is in Christ. See Epistle.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: First, I own the later part, but not the first part of this obiection: Secondly, Iustification is in Christ, and by him purchased; also it is in the conscience, by faith applyed: See my answer to your Epistle.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: Secondly, Then faith doth not iustifie, for it takes not sin out of the conscience.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: 1. This Obiection doth not say, faith iustifieth, or takes sin out of the conscience: but secondly,, God by giving faith doth (by degrees) take sin out of the conscience, Acts 15.9. Hebr. 9.14. And he that begins this good work, wil perfect it til the day of Christ: Phi. 1.6. Pro. 4.18.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 3. Men may believe, and not see sin taken out of their consciences, Is. 50.10, 11 to see all sin taken out of the conscience, is a great light.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: The light is as great, to see our selves iustified, as to see all sin taken out of our consciences: for (as you have said) to be iustified, is to be made iust; and made iust, we are not, till our injustice be done away: neither is that done away, while it abideth in the conscience. Also I have not yet forgotten your once minding this to be the summe of all; That while Christ was one the crosse, he tooke away, and utterly destroyed all his peoples sinnes, for ever: If all their fins were then destroyed, not in part onely, but utterly (not for a little while, but) for ever: how can they now have being in the conscience, if took away, then and that for ever, how can they still remain?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p:
4. If the knowing I believe, takes away my sinne, faith doth not; for to believe is one thing & to know it is
another; and so, neither God, nor his Spirit, nor Christ, nor faith, a part or together, takes them away: but the knowing we believe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: To say faith, or the knowing we believe, takes fin out of the conscience, are your expressions not ours: but we doe and will say, That God purifies our hearts by faith, Acts 15.9.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.p: 5. If assurance of justification, be justification, then are some believers unjustified, which have sin in their consciences, and are deserted, and enjoy not assurance, Ps. 88. Sixtly, If justification consisteth in taking fin out of the conscience, then every act of sin maketh us unjustified, till we act faith to take it out of the conscience, and then we appear to God justified, and unjustified in ten minutes: and then we have not faith, till we have assurance, or till fin be taken out of our conscience; and so such children of God as walke in darknesse, are concluded to be in their finues.
Iustification dependeth not on our believing it; but he that saveth us, justifieth us; even Christ onely; who is our justification, salvation, and all in all.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: 1. We do not say assurance of justification, is justification. Secondly, Every act of sin is injustice: and therefore we are not justified, or made just, while acts of sin remain. Thirdly, That we appear to God iustified now, and then uniustified again, will not follow: but being already iustified in respect of purpose, prophesie, promise and purchase (as was shewen) we thus appear to God now, and shall doe till we are iustified in accomplishment and per formance: the crown of righteousnesse is now safely laid up for us; and shall at that day be given to us: as 2 Tim. 4.8.

4. Though we are not iustified till iniustice be taken out of our consciences, yet faith is before that time. First God by (giving) faith purifies, Acts 15.9. Secondly, faith pitcheth on things to come; it evidenceth things not seen Hebr. 11.1.

Fiftly, Though iustification and salvation, depend not on believing, yet it followeth believing: and though Christ iustifieth and saveth, and is all in all, &c. he iustifieth, and saveth believers onely, and is all in all onely to them, as proved from Rom. 3.22.25. & 4.24. & 10.4.9.10.
